Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dissecting the Role of RSH Extensin in Assembly of the Plant Cell Wall
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kieliszewski/Cannon Proposal Abstract
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Dissecting the role of RSH extensin
in assembly of the plant cell wall

The plant cell wall is a self-assembling structure whose properties arise from correct assembly. Malfunctions in wall assembly can result in the early death of the plant, as occurs with the Arabidopsis rsh embryo lethal mutant, the focus of this proposal. The rsh mutant cannot assemble a functional cell wall in dividing cells because it lacks a specific hydroxyproline-rich glycoprotein, notably a crosslinking extensin designated RSH (ROOT-SHOOT-HYPOCOTYL-DEFECTIVE). This mutant will enable us to dissect the precise rules for wall self-assembly at a molecular level. Mutant plants will be cured of their defect by transferring a range of new RSH genes that might replace the function of the gene that is missing. These complementation experiments with a series of RSH analogs will enable us to define the contributions RSH makes to cell wall assembly.

The strategy involves manipulations of the wild-type gene and analogs that will be produced through synthetic genes. RSH is ideally suited for a synthetic gene approach as it is a simple, highly repetitive protein. Certain amino acids, including lysine, tyrosine, serine and histidine may be crucial to assemble RSH and help it crosslink it to form a scaffold in the plant cell wall, therefore genes will be made that give rise to RSH proteins altered in their content of these amino acids and the ability of these genes to cure the mutant will be evaluated. Other designer RSH molecules will lack part of one extreme end of the protein (N-terminus) or the other (C-terminus) as preliminary results indicate one end in particular, the C-terminus of RSH, is required for wall assembly. Finally naturally-occurring RSH, the RSH analogs and Arabidopsis cell walls will be characterized biochemically.

Broader Impact: The long term goal of defining the molecular interactions of RSH in the plant cell wall, and the precise roles played by the different sections and amino acids in RSH are relevant to understanding how the wall self-assembles, including understanding plant defense responses and how plant form is created. A broader biotechnological value includes new insights into the rules of supramolecular chemistry; the design of versatile molecules that direct the self-assembly of matter at a molecular level is a key goal of nanotechnology. Finally, as the most abundant biomass, plant cell walls at all levels from forest to food to fibre to fuel, contribute crucially to self-sustaining civilizations.

This work also integrates cell wall biology and biochemistry in a way that teaches junior researchers to identify a significant biological problem and set about solving it through collaboration that integrates methods ranging from protein design and characterization to molecular genetics and cell biology. To a greater or lesser extent, both University of Massachusetts and Ohio University have diverse student bodies ensuring that minority students and women form a significant part of the team. Both Dr. Cannon and Dr. Kieliszewski already take part in outreach activities relevant to increasing diversity in the sciences, including outreach to Appalachia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals have skeletons to keep them erect, while plants have walls surrounding every cell. The walls are dynamic molecular structures that function while they expand to allow cell growth. As plants get older the walls get thicker and stronger, and eventually form the largest and in most cases, the most valuable part of the plant, that is for human use. All civilizations from the earliest times used plant cell walls as food, fiber and fuel; even fossil fuels were once cell walls. Understanding cell wall biology is fundamental to maximizing its use. For the plant, cell walls are essential for growth and development. Structurally cell walls are composites of interpenetrating polymers, mainly cellulose, hemicellulose, and pectins, while the less-well studied glycoprotein-based polymers, the extensins (EXTs) are a minor albeit significant component.

There are 20 classical EXTs in the model plant Arabidopsis. These structural type glycoproteins have been difficult to study because they are recalcitrant to purification due to crosslinking. Their hallmark is that each EXT has repetitive sequences of very few different amino acids, and EXTs are very homologous to each other thus the usual methods of identifying individual EXTs and finding out exactly where each is located in the wall has proven difficult. We found a way forward in 2002 when a recessive lethal embryo mutant of EXT3 was identified. We found that EXT3 was essential for new wall assembly at cell division, because without it the walls were defective and incomplete. This allowed us to test EXT analogs for function; we could now dissect EXT3 by making analogs where amino acids and motifs were either deleted or substituted and then test each for ability to rescue the ext3 mutant. This plan would allow us to find out which amino acids are essential and to identify the minimum EXT sequences required for function. The plan also allowed us to test if the other EXTs in the plant had similar or different function to that of EXT3.

Findings made during the course of this project:

•  Certain amino acids are required for function while some others are not, and the N-terminus plus 8.5 rather than the native 13 repeats of 28 amino acids are the maximum required.

•  Although expressed at the same locations and timing as EXT3, six of the other EXTs tested did not rescue the ext3 mutant indicating that not all EXTs have identical functions. This is important because a long-standing question has been ‘Do all EXTs have the same function or are they ‘tailor made’ for some cell types or some environmental conditions’?

These findings contribute to our fundamental knowledge of new cell wall assembly, and in doing so, to plant growth and development broadly. This knowledge puts us in a position to design EXTs and test their effects on plant phenotype. Since EXT3 is essential for new wall assembly, it is conceivable that EXT analogs can be made that alter the cell wall for various purposes.
